Key terms and definitions.What is a redox reaction: A chemical reaction that involves the transfer of electrons between two species
Key terms and definitions.What is reduction: A chemical reaction where a species decreases its oxidation number by gaining electrons
Key terms and definitions.What is oxidation: A chemical reaction where a species increases its oxidation number by losing electrons
Key terms and definitions.What is an oxidising agent/oxidant: A species that oxidises another substance and is itself reduced
Key terms and definitions.What is a reducing agent/reductant: A species that reduces another substance and is itself oxidised
Key terms and definitions.What is an oxidation number: A number assigned to an element that represents the number of electrons lost or gained by an atom of that element to form a chemical bond with another species
Key terms and definitions.What is a conjugate redox pair: An electron donor (reducing agent) and its corresponding electron acceptor

Oxidation numbers.What is the oxidation number of a simple: The number is equal to the charge of the ion
Oxidation numbers.What is the sum of oxidation numbers in: The sum is equal to the charge of the polyatomic ion

Key terms and definitions.What is an electrochemical series: An arrangement of chemical species in order of their reducing and oxidising strength
Key terms and definitions.What is a redox half equation: One of two equations (oxidation or reduction) which describes one half of a redox reaction

Balancing redox equations.How do you balance hydrogen under acidic: Balance the hydrogen using H[+] ions
Balancing redox equations.How do you balance hydrogen under alkali: Balance as you would under acidic conditions, then add OH[-] to both sides of the equations, which makes H[+] become water
Balancing redox equations.What must be kept in mind when balancing: The charges of both equations must be equal, you can multiply the equations to get the same number of electrons in each before adding the equations together

Predicting spontaneous redox reactions.Which species will be oxidised when Iron: Silver is a stronger oxidant than iron, and as such Iron solid will be oxidised to form aqueous Iron ions

Key terms and definitions.What is a galvanic cell: An electrochemical cell in which chemical energy from spontaneous redox reactions is converted into electrical energy
Key terms and definitions.What is an anode: The negatively charged electrode in a galvanic cell where oxidation occurs
Key terms and definitions.What is a cathode: The positively charged electrode in a galvanic cell where reduction occurs
Key terms and definitions.What is a salt bridge: A connection that allows the flow of ions between two half cells to maintain the electrical neutrality of the cell
Key terms and definitions.What is an electrode: An electrical conductor that is either unreactive or involved in a reaction

Key terms and definitions.What are primary cells: Non-rechargeable electrochemical cells in which a chemical reaction generates electrical energy
Key terms and definitions.What are secondary cells: Rechargeable electrochemical cells in which a chemical reaction generates electrical energy
Key terms and definitions.What is meant by the term 'recharge': The conversion of electrical energy into electrical energy through redox reactions with the aid of an external power supply
Key terms and definitions.What is meant by the term 'discharge': The conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy as a result of spontaneous redox reactions
Key terms and definitions.What are batteries: Devices consisting of cells that convert chemical energy to electrical energy

Primary cells.Why are primary cells problematic: As they cannot be recharged, they produce a lot of potentially harmful waste
Primary cells.True/False: Primary cells can undergo re: False, they can undergo discharge only
Primary cells.What factors prevent primary cells from:
In order for a cell to be recharged it must meet the following conditions: 
- The products of the cell reaction must remain in contact with their electrodes 
- The products must be in a form that allows it to be converted back to its original reactant form 
- An external power supply must be present to drive the non-spontaneous redox reactions

Secondary cells.Why must secondary cells be connected to: The reactions required to convert the products of the discharge back to their reactant form are non-spontaneous reactions. And as such a source of energy is required to drive these reactions
Secondary cells.True/False: Secondary cells require a po: False, they require a power supply with a voltage higher than that of the cell

Factors affecting battery life and capac.What does battery life refer to: The extent to which a battery can power something or the number of recharge-discharge cycles a battery can undergo before it dies
Factors affecting battery life and capac.How do high temperatures effect battery: As the temperature increases, so does the rate of side reactions, which will decrease the battery life
Factors affecting battery life and capac.How do low temperatures effect battery c: As the temperature decreases, so does the capacity of the battery because the cell reaction rate decreases, producing less electrical energy
